fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The associated simplicial fiber bundle of twisted products admits a simpler description. Suppose we have simplicial sets F, B, a simplicial group G with an action G \times F \to F and a twisting function \tau on B. The associated twisted product B \times_\tau F is defined exactly the same as twisted products, except we replace the factor G with F. This still makes sense, because we can interpret the multiplication \tau(b) \cdot \partial_n f as the G-action.

In particular, if we consider G as a simplicial set with a G-action on the left via multiplication, then the associated twisted product B \times_\tau G is exactly the same as the twisted product B \times_\tau G, which explains our identical notation.

Given a simplicial principal fiber bundle p : E \to B with simplicial group G, and a simplicial set F with a group action G \times F \to F, we can construct a fiber bundle with fiber F, such that the twisting behaviour is described by the principal bundle p.

We consider a group action on E \times F, by g \cdot (e, f) = (e \cdot g^{-1}, g \cdot f). This action is clearly free. Suppose the quotient simplicial set is E', then we have a simplicial fiber bundle p' : E' \to B induced from p. There is a G-action on the fibers, by acting on the F factor.

Given a simplicial set B, a simplicial group G with a twisting function \tau, the twisted product is the pullback B \times_{{\bar{W}} G} {W} G with the W-bar construction. We write B \times_\tau G so as to make explicit the twisting function. This is a simplicial principal fiber bundle.

More explicitly, we define B \times_\tau G to be the same as the Cartesian product B \times G, but with one face map altered. The pair (b, g) represents the element in B \times_{{\bar{W}} G} {W} G whose first component is b \in B, and the second component is (g_0, \dots, g_n) \in {W} G, where each element is an iterated product \begin{aligned} g_n &= g \\ g_{k-1} &= \tau(\partial_{k+1} \cdots \partial_n b) \cdot (\partial_{k} g_{k}). \end{aligned} This forces the last face map to be \partial_n (b, g) = (\partial_n b, \tau(b) \cdot \partial_n g), and the other face and degeneracy maps are unchanged.

Given a simplicial group G, a twisting function on a simplicial set B is a simplicial map B \to {\bar{W}} G to the W-bar construction. It represents a cocycle valued in G. Recall that ({\bar{W}} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}. Taking the face map \partial_{n} reveals that all but the last component of the map B_n \to ({\bar{W}} G)_n are determined by the lower dimension maps. Hence we can obtain a more minimalistic combinatorial description.
